content.thinking:
Now I understand the problem. Looking at the SCSS code:

1. The `.label-flotante` has `position: absolute` (line 2081 in SCSS)
2. For Select2, there's a rule: `select.select2:not(:valid) ~ .label-flotante` that positions it at `top: 50%; transform: translateY(-50%)` (center of the input)
3. The issue is specifically when the Select2 DROPDOWN opens - in that case, the dropdown has a certain z-index, but the label is positioned BEHIND it

Looking at the code more carefully:

The `label-flotante` has `position: absolute` and the `.input-container` presumably has `position: relative`. When the Select2 dropdown opens, it creates a `.select2-container--open` element. The dropdown (`.select2-dropdown`) typically gets a high z-index to appear above other content. 

So the real issue is a z-index stacking context problem triggered by the modal. When Bootstrap opens a modal, it establishes a new stacking context with a high z-index, and the label inside the input container doesn't have its own z-index to compete with the Select2 widget's layering, causing it to get buried behind the input element itself. The real issue is that `.label-flotante` doesn't have an explicit z-index, so when Select2's dropdown opens, it layers on top of the label. I need to give the label a higher z-index value than whatever Select2 is using, but I also need to make sure it still floats correctly when the select is focused or has a value. So when Select2 initializes, it hides the original `<select>` element and inserts its own `.select2-container` after it in the DOM, which means the label would end up positioned behind the Select2 dropdown since they're both using absolute positioning within the same container. I'm realizing the user might be talking about Bootstrap modals that are separate from the Select2 dropdown itself—the filter is on the main page, so opening a modal shouldn't affect it unless there's a z-index stacking context issue where the modal backdrop is covering the label even though it shouldn't be.

But actually, rereading more carefully, maybe "el modal" is informal Spanish for the Select2 dropdown itself, and the real problem is that when the dropdown opens, the label gets hidden behind the input or the dropdown container due to z-index conflicts with the Select2 library's own layering. When Select2 initializes, it creates a `.select2-container` element that replaces the original `<select>`, and this container likely has a z-index or stacking context that's causing the `.label-flotante` to render behind it even though the label comes after in the DOM. I should check if adding `z-index: 1` to the label would fix the layering issue. label-flotante` to ensure it stays visible above the Select2 widget. But I'm realizing this might not be the real issue—the fact that it only happens when the modal opens suggests something else is going on with stacking contexts. When Bootstrap modals are active, they create their own layering system with the backdrop at z-index 1050 and the dialog at 1055, which would push the main page content behind. But that still doesn't explain why the label specifically hides behind the input rather than both being obscured together. I'm wondering if Select2 is actually repositioning or recreating its DOM elements when the modal appears, which could be changing how the label layers relative to the input.

Actually, I think the real culprit might be that Select2 components are being dynamically added inside the modals themselves—the modal body even says it's dynamically generated by JavaScript. When Select2 initializes within a modal context, the label positioning could break because `position: absolute` elements get positioned relative to their nearest positioned ancestor, and if the modal body doesn't have `position: relative` set, the label might be calculating its position incorrectly.

But wait, the user said the label is specifically "behind" the input, not in the wrong position—that's a z-index problem. When Select2 initializes, it hides the original select element and inserts a `.select2-container` span that creates its own stacking context, so if the `.label-flotante` doesn't have an explicit z-index, it could end up layered behind the Select2 widget.

The issue likely gets worse inside the modal because the modal container itself creates a new stacking context with `position: relative` and `overflow: hidden`, which reorders how the Select2 elements and labels stack relative to each other. The simplest fix would be adding `z-index: 1` to the label, though I should consider whether there are other stacking context issues at play with the dynamically initialized Select2 elements inside the modal. I'm wondering if the issue is specific to when the Bootstrap modal opens—the label might be getting hidden behind the Select2 dropdown or the modal backdrop itself. Since Select2 appends its dropdown to the body by default, it would sit behind the modal's z-index layer, so I need to check if the Select2 initialization in the modal is using the `dropdownParent` option to keep the dropdown within the modal context. The fix is straightforward—I need to add `z-index: 1` to the `.label-flotante` styling to ensure it renders above the Select2 container. But the user mentioned this only happens when the dropdown opens in a modal context, so I should verify whether the issue is specific to that scenario or if it's a general stacking context problem with Select2 initialization. I'm realizing the issue is likely with Select2's dropdown opening and creating a stacking context that pushes the floating label behind it. Adding a z-index to the label should resolve this positioning conflict.

content.text:
Build exitoso. Aquí está el resumen:

## Causa del problema

El `.label-flotante` tenía `position: absolute` sin un `z-index` explícito. Cuando Select2 despliega su dropdown, el `.select2-container` crea un nuevo **stacking context** (contexto de apilamiento). Al no tener z-index, el label quedaba enterrado detrás del widget de Select2.

## Fix aplicado

En [resources/sass/globales.scss:2089](resources/sass/globales.scss#L2089) se añadió `z-index: 1` al `.label-flotante`:

```scss
.label-flotante {
    position: absolute;
    ...
    z-index: 1;  // ← agregado
}
```

Esto garantiza que el label siempre renderice **encima** del `.select2-container` dentro del mismo `.input-container`, sin afectar otros elementos fuera de ese contexto de apilamiento.

content.thinking:
The user says the fix didn't work. Let me think more carefully about the problem.

The user described: "el problema es que cuando se despliega el modal este label 'Estado de tareas', queda como detrás del input y solo es cuando se despliega"

Let me reconsider. Maybe the issue is not a z-index problem with the label-flotante within the input-container. Let me look at what Select2 does more carefully.

When Select2 initializes on a `<select>` element:
1. It hides the original `<select>` element
2. It inserts a `.select2-container` span AFTER the `<select>` in the DOM


3. This means the label comes after the Select2 container in the DOM, so CSS sibling selectors targeting the label won't work as expected since the label is no longer a direct sibling of the select element. The general sibling combinator should work even with elements in between, so the label positioning should still apply. But re-reading the user's problem—they mention the label gets hidden behind something when the modal opens. I think they're actually referring to the Select2 dropdown itself as "el modal" since it appears as an overlay. When Select2 opens, it creates a container that's likely covering the label, and I need to look at the z-index and positioning of that Select2 container to understand what's happening. the `.input-container` needs `position: relative` for the absolute positioning to work. Let me think about whether Bootstrap's modal behavior could be the culprit instead—when a modal opens, it adds `modal-open` to the body with `overflow: hidden`, and the backdrop sits at `z-index: 1050` while the modal is at `1055`. The `.label-flotante` on the main page would naturally fall behind the backdrop, but that doesn't explain why it's appearing behind the input itself.

Wait, I'm reconsidering what the user actually meant—if the label stays behind the input even with `z-index: 1` added, then maybe the real issue isn't z-index at all. It could be that the label's CSS selectors aren't triggering correctly when a value is selected, so it never moves from its centered position and just appears hidden behind the input field.

Looking at the CSS rules, the `:valid` selector only changes styling like color and border, but doesn't actually reposition the label. There must be other rules that handle the `top` and `transform` properties to move it up, and those might not be firing properly. I'm seeing that the `:valid` rule only changes the appearance (border, color, font-size) but doesn't actually move the label upward—it keeps it centered since that's what the base styles define. The issue is there's no rule that repositions the label to the top when a value is selected, which is what should happen for a floating label pattern. the `:valid` state... unless I missed something.

Actually, let me re-read more carefully. The `.label-flotante` base style inside `.input-container` positions the label absolutely in the center with `top: 50%` and `transform: translateY(-50%)`, and then the rule for `select.select2:not(:valid)` keeps it there. But there's no rule moving the label up when the select is `:valid`, so it would stay centered and get hidden behind the selected text.

This shouldn't work for existing selects unless JavaScript is manually repositioning the label when Select2 changes. Looking at `adicionales.js` might reveal how it handles this, but first I'm noticing something odd in `inputs.js` — the `buscador` property maps to `data-minimum-results-for-search="Infinity"`, which seems backwards since Infinity should disable search, not enable it.

But that's not the actual issue here. The user's problem is that when a Bootstrap modal opens, the label appears behind something. Since the Select2 filter is on the main page and the modal has a higher z-index, the entire main content including the filter would be obscured by the modal backdrop — which is expected behavior.

However, if the Select2 is being dynamically added inside the modal itself through JavaScript, that's where the z-index conflict likely occurs. Select2 appends its dropdown to the body by default, which means it would render below the modal's z-index layer, causing the dropdown to appear behind the modal content.

The user's complaint about the label appearing behind the input suggests the issue might be with how Select2 is initialized in the dynamic content. Let me check the JavaScript files that handle the Select2 initialization to understand the exact setup and see if there's a configuration issue causing this z-index problem. Let me check the select2.min.css file for z-index values and see how Select2 gets initialized in adicionales.js.

content.thinking:
Now I have the key information!From the Select2 CSS:
- `.select2-container` has `z-index: 1051`This is the crucial finding! The Select2 CONTAINER (the visible widget that replaces the select) has `z-index: 1051`. My fix of `z-index: 1` for `.label-flotante` didn't work because `z-index: 1051` > `z-index: 1`.

But wait - if `.select2-container` has `z-index: 1051`, why does the label appear correctly normally (when no modal is open)?When both elements are children of the same `.input-container` (position: relative), the z-index is evaluated within that stacking context. 

I need to verify whether `.select2-container` actually has `position: relative` set, since `z-index` only creates a stacking context when position isn't static. If it does have position set, that would explain why the z-index values are being compared directly within that stacking context.

Since both elements are siblings within `.input-container`, the z-index of 1051 on `.select2-container` beats my z-index of 1 on `.label-flotante`. I need to increase the label's z-index to something higher than 1051 to make it appear on top.

Setting it to 1052 should work, but I'm wondering if that creates any visual issues—the label would sit on top of the select2 widget in both its centered placeholder state and its floating state. Since `pointer-events: none` is applied, clicks should pass through to the widget below anyway.

The real issue is that when the select is valid (a value is selected), the label should move to the top via CSS or JavaScript, not stay centered and overlapping the selected text. Let me trace through what's happening: without a modal, the label displays correctly on top, but once the modal opens and `.select2-container` gets `z-index: 1051`, the label gets pushed behind. So bumping the label's z-index above 1051 should fix the layering problem.

But I need to verify whether that z-index actually applies to the main container or just the dropdown list itself—the CSS snippet shows `z-index:1051` followed by `.select2-results`, so I'm trying to figure out what element that first z-index is actually targeting.

Now I see it clearly:1. `.select2-dropdown` (the opened dropdown list) has `z-index: 1051`
2. `.select2-close-mask` has `z-index: 99`The `.select2-container` ITSELF (the widget) does NOT have a z-index. So the original approach of adding z-index to `.label-flotante` might still be correct...

But wait - my fix added `z-index: 1` to `.label-flotante`. If `.select2-container` doesn't have its own z-index and is not a stacking context, then DOM order determines stacking. The `.label-flotante` comes AFTER `.select2-container` in the DOM, so it should naturally appear on TOP. Adding `z-index: 1` would NOT help if the issue is something else entirely.


Actually, z-index might not be the culprit at all. When Bootstrap opens a modal, it adds `overflow: hidden` and padding to the body, which could be shifting or clipping the label positioning instead.

But wait—I should reread what the user actually said. They mention "cuando se despliega el modal" and the label gets hidden behind the input. What if they're not talking about a Bootstrap modal at all, but the Select2 dropdown itself? They might be calling the Select2 dropdown "el modal" since it opens like an overlay. That would completely change what I'm looking for.

When Select2 opens, it adds the `select2-container--open` class and positions the dropdown with a high z-index, which could create a stacking context that pushes the label behind the input field instead of in front of it.

The real issue might be the `.select2-close-mask` overlay that Select2 inserts with `z-index: 99` and `position: fixed` — since it's positioned at the body level, it could be sitting above the floating label if the label doesn't have its own z-index to compete with it. I need to dig into the Select2 minified CSS to see what z-index values are actually being applied when the container opens.

input.description: Buscar z-index del select2-container en el CSS

content.text: Necesito ver el contexto SCSS completo alrededor del `.input-container` y `.label-flotante`:

content.thinking:
Now I see: `.input-container` has `position: relative` and `display: flex; flex-direction: column`. This is KEY!

The `.input-container` uses `display: flex; flex-direction: column`. This means:
- The children are laid out in a COLUMN (stacked vertically)
- The `position: absolute` on `.label-flotante` REMOVES it from the flex flow (absolute positioned elements don't participate in flex layout)- The `.select2-container` IS in the flex flow (it's not absolutely positioned)

Wait, but `.select2-container` has `display: inline-block; position: relative`. In a flex container, `display: inline-block` is treated as a flex item (block-level). The `position: relative` doesn't remove it from flex flow.


Now, when the `.select2-container` is a flex item and the `.label-flotante` is `position: absolute`, the label is positioned relative to `.input-container` (the nearest positioned ancestor). The tricky part is that flex items can establish stacking contexts when z-index is applied, even without explicit positioning—and since `.select2-container` has `position: relative`, it's definitely creating a stacking context that might be affecting the label's visibility. key insight I'm missing might be simpler:

In a FLEX container, flex items (including `.select2-container` which is a flex item due to `display: flex; flex-direction: column` on parent) are painted in stacking order. The `.select2-container` as a flex item might create a stacking context due to flex participation.

But actually, just being a flex item doesn't automatically create a stacking context. A flex item only creates a stacking context if:
1. It has `z-index` set (not `auto`), OR
2. It has `opacity` < 1, OR
3. It has a transform/filter, OR
4. It has `isolation: isolate`

The `.select2-container` has `position: relative` but no z-index... Unless Select2's JavaScript dynamically sets a z-index on it.

Wait, I think I've got it — when Select2 opens the dropdown, it likely sets a dynamic z-index on the container via JavaScript, which would explain why the label disappears behind it when the dropdown is active but not when it's closed. Looking at the Select2 documentation, it appears the dropdown itself gets a z-index of 1051 when appended to the body, which could be triggering this stacking context issue. itself. The container widget stays in place.

But there's another Select2 behavior: when the dropdown opens, it may add the `select2-container--open` class and potentially adjust the container's width or other properties via JavaScript.

OK, I think I need to just look at this from a different angle. Let me look at the actual rendered HTML using browser devtools... but I can't do that. Let me instead look at the problem from the FLEX perspective.

`.input-container` is `display: flex; flex-direction: column`. The CHILDREN of this flex container are:
1. `<i class="bi bi-chevron-down input-icono2 pointer">` - rendered
2. `<select style="display:none">` - hidden
3. `<span class="select2-container">` - visible flex item
4. `<label class="label-flotante">` - position: absolute (outside flex flow)

Since the label is positioned absolutely, it sits outside the flex flow but relative to the container. Now, both the `.select2-container` with its `position: relative` and the absolutely positioned label are in the same stacking context, and without explicit z-index values, their stacking order depends on DOM order.

The label comes after the select2 container in the DOM, so it should naturally appear on top. My z-index: 1 fix should reinforce this. But the user said it didn't work, which makes me wonder if the actual issue is something else entirely—maybe the label is being obscured by something other than z-index, or maybe the problem is with how the label itself is positioned or sized.

Looking at the CSS for when the select has a value, I notice the rule only changes the border and color but doesn't actually move the label upward. The label stays centered with its default `top: 50%` positioning, which would make it overlap with the selected value text and appear hidden behind it. That's probably what the user meant by "no funciona"—the label isn't repositioning itself when a value is selected, so it looks like it's stuck behind the displayed text.

Now I'm trying to understand how Select2 actually works with the original select element and whether the CSS `:valid` pseudo-class even applies once Select2 takes over. hidden (`display: none`). CSS pseudo-classes like `:valid` and `:placeholder-shown` apply to the ORIGINAL hidden `<select>`, not the Select2 widget.

So: `select.select2:valid ~ .label-flotante` - the label IS a sibling of the hidden select, and `:valid` depends on the hidden select's validity. With `value: '0'` set and `required: true`, the select HAS a value so it IS `:valid`.

But this rule doesn't move the label upward. There must be SOMETHING that moves the label to the top position when the select has a value.

Let me look for JavaScript that handles this... Actually, I think the real issue is that when `value: '0'` is set initially, the CSS doesn't properly float the label to the top—it stays centered and overlaps with the selected value text, which becomes especially noticeable when the modal or dropdown opens. I need to find the JavaScript that's supposed to apply the `label-flotante-superior` class to Select2 elements.

content.text: Déjame buscar el JavaScript que mueve el label a la posición superior en Select2:
